data.title: Reporter Reads
data.meta_description: Listen to a selection of stories read aloud by our reporters.
data.text:
Hosting the Olympics Costs Billions. What Does a City Get Back?

The Games are supposed to be a fast track to urban renewal. The reality is often the opposite.

By Michael Kimmelman

From the Playing Field to Wall Street

For more than 200 pro athletes, the boutique investment firm Patricof Co is opening the door to the private equity market.

By Ken Belson

episode

Long After ‘Sexually Speaking,’ Dr. Ruth Taught Me About Friendship

Even when she was talking about sex on her late-night radio show, Dr. Ruth Westheimer was focused on human connections.

By Allison Gilbert

Critic’s Notebook

After 12 Years of Reviewing Restaurants, I’m Leaving the Table

Pete Wells is moving on from his role as the Times restaurant critic, a job with many rewards and maybe too many courses.

By Pete Wells

Critic’s Notebook

‘Hillbilly Elegy’ Gets a Blockbuster Sequel

Our critic traces J.D. Vance’s shift from bootstrap memoirist to vice-presidential candidate.

By A.O. Scott

Promised Cures, Tainted Cells: How Cord Blood Banks Mislead Parents

Families pay thousands of dollars to store their children’s stem cells with the hope of a healthier future. But the cells are rarely useful, and sometimes contaminated.

By Sarah Kliff and Azeen Ghorayshi

How Microsoft’s Satya Nadella Became Tech’s Steely Eyed A.I. Gambler

Microsoft’s all-in moment on artificial intelligence has been defined by billions in spending and a C.E.O. counting on technology with huge potential and huge risks.

By Karen Weise and Cade Metz

Is Cutting Off Your Family Good Therapy?

Encouraged on social media, many Americans are estranging themselves from their families as a therapeutic step.

By Ellen Barry

Is There a Future in the Doomsday Economy?

With Fortitude Ranch, the entrepreneur Drew Miller is betting on franchised timeshares for people who are worried about the end of the world.

By Alexander Nazaryan and Emily Najera

Rebuilding a Life Torn Apart by a Tornado, Piece by Piece

After a tornado killed the grandmother who raised him in rural Mississippi, Jaden Grayson went to live with his uncle in Arkansas, leaving everything he had known behind.

By Rory Doyle and Rick Rojas
